messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last 200 years, technology got better.  
People got better health care.  
Fewer children died young.  
These families had many children.  
Many children grew up.  
They had children too.  
Contraception means ways to stop a woman having a baby.  
In the 1960s, people could use contraception.  
At first, women had six babies on average.  
Then they had two babies on average.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.863 is below the required 0.90. Key terms like 'fuelling rapid population growth' were removed, and 'global average number of babies per woman' was simplified, losing important lexical detail. Suggestion: Restore 'fuelling rapid population growth' in one sentence. Use 'global average number of babies per woman' instead of 'women had ... babies on average'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last 200 years, technology got better.  
People got better health care.  
Fewer children died young.  
These changes are fuelling rapid population growth.  
Families had many children.  
Many children grew up and had children too.  
Contraception is how people stop a woman having a baby.  
In the 1960s, people could use contraception.  
The global average number of babies per woman was six.  
Then it fell to two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8834 is below the required 0.90. This low score shows a significant loss of key lexical content from the original.
- The phrase "wider availability of" before contraception was omitted, reducing the original specificity.
- A new definition sentence "Contraception is how people stop a woman having a baby." adds content not in the original and shifts focus.
- The expression "as low as two" was simplified to "it fell to two", removing the nuance of decline limits.
Suggestion: Reintroduce the exact phrase "wider availability of contraception", restore the wording "as low as two", and remove added definitions to improve lexical overlap and fidelity.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last 200 years, technology got better.  
People got better health care.  
Fewer children died young.  
So the number of people grew fast.  
Families had many children.  
Many children grew up.  
They had children too.  
In the 1960s, there was a wider availability of contraception.  
Contraception means ways to stop having a baby.  
The average number of babies per woman was six.  
Then it fell to as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Fidelity Failure. BERTScore of 0.8781 is below the required 0.90. The writer’s output drops the phrase “global average” and replaces “rapid population growth” with the generic “the number of people grew fast,” losing key terminology. Suggestion: Reinsert “global average number of babies per woman” and retain “rapid population growth” to preserve lexical fidelity.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last 200 years, technology got better.  
People got better health care.  
Fewer children died young.  
So there was rapid population growth.  
Families had many children.  
Many children grew up.  
They had children too.  
In the 1960s, people could use contraception more.  
Contraception is how people stop having a baby.  
The global average number of babies per woman was six.  
Then it fell to as low as two.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8801 is below the required 0.90, indicating a loss of precise phrasing and key lexical detail. Deviations detected:
- The phrase "rapid population growth" is split into two sentences, diluting the core idea of rapid change.
- "Wider availability of contraception" is rendered as "people could use contraception more", losing the nuance of increased access.
- The global statistic is broken: "The global average number of babies per woman was six. Then it fell to as low as two." This split undermines the original cohesive presentation.
Suggestion: Merge related facts into unified sentences. Restore precise terms like "rapid population growth" and "wider availability of contraception." Use a single sentence for the statistic on babies per woman to maintain cohesion.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last 200 years, technology and health care got better.  
Fewer children died young.  
This made the population grow fast.  
Families had many children.  
The children grew up and had children too.  
But in the 1960s, contraception became easier to get.  
Contraception is how people stop having a baby.  
The world average babies per woman fell from six to two.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7395 is below the required 0.75. The original phrase ‘fueling rapid population growth’ conveys a strong causal link, but your version ‘This made the population grow fast’ loses that precise nuance. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8931 is below the required 0.90. Key terms like ‘wider availability of contraception’ were reduced to ‘easier to get’, and ‘global average number of babies per woman’ became ‘world average babies per woman’, which weakens the original detail. Suggestion: Restore ‘fueling rapid population growth’, use ‘wider availability of contraception’, and keep ‘global average number of babies per woman’ for full fidelity.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two hundred years, technology and health care improved.
Fewer children died young.
This fueled rapid population growth.
Families had many children.
The children grew up and had children too.
But in the 1960s, there was a wider availability of contraception.
Contraception is a way to stop having a baby.
The global average number of babies per woman was six.
It fell to two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6791 is below the required 0.75.
- The phrase "as low as" was dropped, changing the nuance of the decline to an exact drop from six to two.
- The original detail "large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood and had their own children" was simplified to two separate sentences, losing the sense of cumulative effect.
- Adding a definition of contraception shifts focus away from the demographic narrative and disrupts the flow.
Suggestion: Reinstate the qualifier "as low as" for the drop in birth rate, merge the cause-and-effect clauses into a single describe of population growth, and remove the side definition of contraception to keep the original emphasis and sequence of ideas.

Text saved: In the last two hundred years, technology and health care improved.  
Fewer children died young.  
This made the population grow fast.  
Big families had many children who lived and then had children too.  
In the 1960s, more people could get contraception.  
The global average number of babies per woman was six.  
It fell to as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 5/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text uses a B1 word and misses needed A2 definitions. Detected issues:
- The word “global” is classified as B1 vocabulary and exceeds A2 level.
- The key term “contraception” is listed as a keyword but is not defined in simple A2 language.
- The connector “then” is not in the allowed set (and, but, so, because).
Suggestion: Replace “global” with “world” or “in the world.” Add a simple definition for contraception, e.g. “contraception means ways to stop a woman from getting pregnant.” Remove or replace “then” with an allowed connector like “and” or restructure the sentence.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two hundred years, technology and health care improved.  
Because of this, fewer children died young and population grew fast.  
Parents had large families and many children lived to be adults.  
Those adults had children too.  
In the 1960s, more people could use contraception.  
The average number of babies per woman declined from six.  
It fell to as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1.  
- The sentence “Because of this, fewer children died young and population grew fast.” begins with the subordinating link “Because of this,” a structure above A2.  
- The comparative adjective “fewer” is a B1-level word.  
- The noun phrase “average number of babies per woman” is too complex for A2.  
- The idiomatic expression “as low as two” reflects a B1 phrase.  
- The time phrase “in the 1960s” introduces advanced decade notation.  
Suggestion: Start sentences simply without “Because of this.” Use basic words like “not many” instead of “fewer.” Replace “average number of babies per woman” with “how many babies each woman had.” Remove the idiom “as low as.” Use only “and” for links.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two hundred years, technology and health care improved.  
Not many children died young.  
The population grew fast.  
Parents had large families.  
Many children lived to be adults.  
Those adults had children too.  
In 1960, more people could use contraception.  
Contraception is a way to stop pregnancy.  
Then each woman had six babies.  
Now each woman has two babies.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5897 is below the required 0.75, showing the writer lost the nuanced core message about declining child mortality rates driving population growth and subsequent fertility changes. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8728 is below the required 0.90, indicating key phrases like "global average" and the timeline progression from the 1960s are missing or oversimplified. Suggestion: Restore the phrase "global average number of babies per woman" and the decline "from six babies per woman to as low as two". Reintroduce the link between fewer child deaths and rapid population growth to preserve the original meaning.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Technology and health care improved in the last two hundred years. Because of that, fewer children died when they were young. So the world population grew fast. Families had many children. Many of those children lived to become adults. They had children of their own. In the 1960s, people could use contraception more easily. Contraception is a way to stop a woman from getting pregnant. Then the global average number of babies per woman was six. Today it is as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7048 is below the required 0.75.
Detected deviations:
- The causal connection ‘fuelling rapid population growth’ is lost when splitting into separate short sentences.
- The decline from six to two babies per woman is not clearly framed as a direct result of contraception.
Suggestion: Merge sentences to restore the cause–effect link (use phrasing like “fuelling rapid population growth”) and explicitly state that the average fell from six to two babies per woman after the 1960s.

Contraception is a way to stop a woman getting pregnant.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Technology and health care improved in the last two hundred years.  
Fewer children died young.  
Population grew.  
Large families had more children who survived.  
These children had their own children.  
In the 1960s, contraception, a way to stop pregnancy, became easier.  
The average number of babies per woman in the world declined.  
It declined from six babies per woman to as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance Deep Audit. The text passes factual integrity and metric checks but fails A2 vocabulary and structure. Detected words outside the A1/A2 lists: improved, grew, survived, declined, became. The relative clause “children who survived” is a B1 structure. The term “pregnancy” is at C1 level. Suggestion: Replace improved with got better; grew with got bigger; survived with lived; declined with went down; became with got. Remove the clause who survived by saying children lived to adulthood. Replace pregnancy with having babies. Use only and, but, so, because as connectors.
